Description: Upper portion of a granite obelisk featuring divine images across each side. Each side features relief scenes of a seated deity and a kneeling figure before them making an offering. Two relief scenes with a kneeling king include the seated image of the god Amun, identifiable via his two feather crown. The other scenes include the gods Atum and Re-Horakhty being provided with offerings. Below these scenes were clearly further representations and lines of incised text, which are now obscured. The top of the obelisk has been broken off. The obelisk is now supported on a slim modern mount.
Curator's comments: The king depicted making offerings has been suggested to represent Sety I, which would then provide the obelisk with a 19th Dynasty date.
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2002, St Albans, Life and Death
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Sety I (?)
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Sir Robert Ludwig Mond
